content.text: Baby’s body becomes physiologically prepared for the rolling milestone by recognizing all body sides: tummy time, lying on the back, and lying on the right and left sides without any assistance. Baby brings their hands toward the midline of the body and puts their palms in their mouth. They shift their balance from one side of the body to the other while lying on the tummy or back.
Primitive reflexes must resolve before baby can achieve voluntary control over motor movements. This stage also physiologically prepares the body for the rolling stage.

If you see that your baby is having a hard time achieving this milestone by the age of 4 months, you should consult with your pediatrician or an infant development guide to learn how to help your baby. These important abilities are the foundation of their physical, sensory and emotional needs.
By the end of this period, you’ll want to see your baby doing the following:

ul: Lying on their tummy for 10 minutes and being comfortable and relaxed.
Lying on their back and playing with a toy with both hands.
Lying on both the left and right sides comfortably.
Relaxing while being held in a cradling hold.
Lifting their head while lying on their belly and looking forward and to the sides.
Putting their head down when they are awake and relaxed.
Being comfortable with changes, i.e., when you change their position or let someone else hold them.
Keep their palms open most of the time.
